data.title: Maven repo usage - feature request
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Who knows, it is not under help menu, can be a new feature.
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04

Steps to Reproduce:

I tried to use "maven mate plugin" without success.

I think the java editor is useless, if i cannot attach jar files or folder to the project, but it would be very easy, if i can just point out to my maven repository, and it can figure out the libraries according to the pom file. (It is not necessary to make a maven build, but it would be good if i can browse my project, wherever there is java source)

data.title: Append --noLazy to runtimeArgs
data.body:
We used to have runtimeArgs: ["--noLazy"] in intial launch.json configuration, however since we simplifed the initial launch.json this got removed.
We should always append this value on the node-debug side since it allows a smoother breakpoint setting experience

data.title: Ruby: SQL heredoc not colorizing the embedded code
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Version 1.5.3 (1.5.3)
- OS Version: OS X El Capitan 10.11.5 (15F34)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create a `test.rb` file
2. Type:

``` ruby
query = <<-SQL
  SELECT COUNT(*) FROM "table" WHERE "column" = 'foo'
SQL
```

Expectation: the contents of the heredoc-delimited string should be colorized as SQL
What happens: It gets colorized as a string, with the exception of `COUNT`, that receives the same colorization of a regex

![screen shot 2016-10-10 at 17 55 18](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/425406/19242288/cd0b2fdc-8f12-11e6-8a94-93dbb70fd51c.png)

data.title: VSCode freezes after a few minutes of work on a network folder
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.3
- OS Version: Windows 7 64 bit

Steps to Reproduce:
1.  Open a folder located on the network (it can be a either a SMB folder or a WebDAV mounted drive)
2.  Open the same file in two editors side by side (it's a CSS file in my case)
3.  Work for a few minutes by making changes and saving several times
4.  VS Code freezes and it should be restarted (please look at the screenshot)

![vscode_crash](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1380443/19239366/f9f5b25e-8f05-11e6-988c-4dd6a487afda.PNG)

data.title: Feature: Support Multiple Version of the Same of Extension(s)
data.body: Is it possible to add ability to support and subscribe to multiple version/build/branch of the same extension(s)? This would allow users to opt-in and subscribe to a beta or development branch of an extension without the need to install another addon (eg [Node Debug](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=ms-vscode.node-debug2) and [TS and JS Grammar](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=ms-vscode.typescript-javascript-grammar)) or manual install an addon (eg [PowerShell](https://github.com/PowerShell/vscode-powershell/issues/311)). My vision of this feature would allow the user to easily switch between branches from the Extension UI if the extension developer exposes the different versions via the extension manifest.

data.title: Support multi target debugging
data.body:
Support multiple debug sessions in a single instance of VS Code.

This helps with the following scenarios:
- debug a client and a server
- debug a clustered program
- debug a multi process application
- debug an extension and its debug adapter and/or language server at the same time

Problems to address:
- multiple debug models or one 'super model'?
- how to launch multiple sessions with a single 'F5'?
- UI: Process view vs. Windows vs. tabs...

data.title: Show inline values in source when stepping through code
data.body:
1. in the debug protocol add a scope boundary (start, end position) to the scope object.
2. implement this in node-debug2.
3. VS Code starts to use that information to fix the hover experience by only showing a hover when inside the scope boundaries.
4. node.debug2 and (node-debug) implement the one line 'preview' for objects and arrays. This is not a new protocol request but just improves what's get returned as the `value`attribute in a Variables request for objects and arrays. 
5. VS Code implements the 'show inline values' feature as outlined in #12256

data.title: Feature Requestp
data.body: When we hover our mouse on a method, VS code will provide its help docs in a flowing window, however it is scrolled to the end of the help document automatically. For those method with long documents, we can't see the beginning part of the help documents, which is always the most important part. A scrollbar like peek window in Visual Studio 2015 maybe a solution for this.

data.title: Non-menu bar shortcuts are mapped incorrectly on Dvorak
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.3
- OS Version: 10.12.0

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Set keyboard layout to Dvorak
2. Use a keyboard shortcut that isn't in the system menu bar. For example, `Cmd+Shift+]` for indent.
3. Code zooms the interface, as the physical key for `]` in Dvorak is `=`.

Shortcuts that are defined in the menu bar work correctly as they are handled by the system.

Other keyboard layouts where symbol keys are remapped may exhibit the same problem.

data.title: Change extension recommendations to be dynamic
data.body:
Recommendations currently come from two curated lists. The first is one we want to keep, we call them **important recommendations** and only essential extensions exist within; these recommendations appear as popus to the user. The second one is an ever growing list of _not-so-important_ extensions, which appear only in the `@recommended` list. We want to replace curation by dynamically querying the Marketplace.

cc @seanmcbreen @waderyan 
## 

We still have to look into whether the tagging currently in place gives us acceptable results. The tagging currently running by [`vsce`](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-vsce/blob/master/src/package.ts#L213) and run as a background task in the Marketplace creates hidden tags `__ext_${EXTENSION}` for extensions. We can then [query for them ](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/search?term=tag%3A__ext_md&target=VSCode&sortBy=Relevance)as users open said files. Eg: if the user opens a `.js` file, we'd search for extensions tagged with the `__ext_js` keyword.

Let's take our current curated suggestions and see whether they would show up given this strategy. Make sure you scroll right to see the full data.

| Recommendation | Files | Current | Next |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| ms-vscode.csharp | `**/*.cs,**/project.json,**/global.json,**/*.csproj,**/*.sln` | 5 | 1 |
| ms-vscode.mono-debug | `**/*.cs,**/*.csproj,**/*.sln` | 3 | 0 |
| msjsdiag.debugger-for-chrome | `**/*.ts,**/*.tsx**/*.js,**/*.jsx,**/*.es6` | 5 | 0 |
| lukehoban.Go | `**/*.go` | 1 | 1 |
| ms-vscode.PowerShell | `**/*.ps,**/*.ps1` | 2 | 0 |
| austin.code-gnu-global | `**/*.c,**/*.cpp,**/*.h` | 3 | 0 |
| Ionide.Ionide-fsharp | `**/*.fsx,**/*.fsi,**/*.fs,**/*.ml,**/*.mli` | 5 | 3 |
| dbaeumer.vscode-eslint | `**/*.js,**/*.jsx,**/*.es6` | 3 | 0 |
| eg2.tslint | `**/*.ts,**/*.tsx` | 2 | 0 |
| Kasik96.format-indent | `**/*.php` | 1 | 0 |
| felixfbecker.php-debug | `**/*.php` | 1 | 0 |
| linyang95.phpmd | `**/*.php` | 1 | 0 |
| ikappas.phpcs | `**/*.php` | 1 | 0 |
| tht13.python | `**/*.py` | 1 | 1 |
| donjayamanne.python | `**/*.py` | 1 | 0 |
| magicstack.MagicPython | `**/*.py` | 1 | 1 |
| saviorisdead.RustyCode | `**/*.rs,**/*.rslib` | 2 | 1 |
| hars.CppSnippets | `**/*.cpp,**/*.cc,**/*.h` | 3 | 0 |
| mitaki28.vscode-clang | `**/*.cpp,**/*.cc,**/*.h` | 3 | 0 |
| ms-vscode.cpptools | `**/*.c,**/*.cpp,**/*.cc,**/.cxx,**/*.hh,**/*.hpp,**/*.hxx,**/*.h` | 8 | 0 |
| seanmcbreen.Spell | `**/*.md` | 1 | 0 |
| ms-vscode.Theme-MarkdownKit | `**/*.md` | 1 | 0 |
| DavidAnson.vscode-markdownlint | `**/*.md` | 1 | 0 |
| PeterJausovec.vscode-docker | `**/dockerfile,**/Dockerfile,**/docker-compose.yml,**/docker-compose.*.yml` | 5 | 0 |
|  |  | 60 | 8 |

In the third column you'll find the number of triggers per recommended extension. A trigger is a file name/extension which we currently use to recommend that extension. For example, `foo.js` triggers the extension `dbaeumer.vscode-eslint`. There are a total of 60 triggers in our current curated list.

Using the `__ext_` keywords, only 8 of those would actually work. That's 13%. This happens because most of these extensions are not tagged with the corresponding keywords based on the file extensions we recommend them from. For example, `msjsdiag.debugger-for-chrome` doesn't specify anything about `.js` files in its manifest.

Then there's the additional problem of queries returning too many extensions. The query for the `__ext_h` keyword alone returns 359 results. Sorting that query by [downloads](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/search?term=tag%3A__ext_h&target=VSCode&category=All%20categories&sortBy=Downloads) or by [rating](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/search?term=tag%3A__ext_h&target=VSCode&category=All%20categories&sortBy=Rating) doesn't seem to help much in narrowing which extensions really are _recommendable_.

Finally, imagining that the `__ext_` keyword queries return a healthy collection of extensions, we need to figure out how to sort that collection and where is the cut-off point between a recommended extension and simply a popular one.

data.title: Emmet completion doesn't work after button with (click) event in typescript with Angular 2.0

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.3 && Same behaviour is seen on the latest Insider Build dated 10.10.2016.
- OS Version: macOS 10.12

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Generate simple angular2 project with angular-cli
2. go to .component.ts file
3. In the `template:` have something like `<button (click)="test = 'Emmet works'"></button>`
4. type the word button on the next like and try to use TAB to autocomplete button element
5. It just uses regular tab instead of emmet completion.

If you try to use tab completion before the aforementioned button click it will auto-complete correctly. 

Removing the (click) part fixes the autocompletion.

data.title: Rename unsaved file should still keep the file content
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.3
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open VS Code, Create a new file name `foo.js` without saving file.
2. Type some content to the file.
3. Right-click on file name, choose Rename and rename it to `foo.js.ts` or `bar.js`.
4. The dialog box appeared warning that "_Your changes will be lost_".
5. Click Rename. 
6. File renamed and all typed text has _gone_.

What I expect is the content of unsaved file **should not lost** in this scenario.
I don't expect any different of typing in **unsaved foo.js** and **unsaved foo.js.ts**.

It is make sense to confuse especially for **Visual Studio** user 
that also has a warning dialog box when renaming file extension too.
But it's asking about file may unusable, so it is automatic for me to accept the 
confirmation box in **Visual Studio Code** too.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/344784/19231529/ae0e15d0-8f04-11e6-85b5-136ec903e2c5.png)
Dialog box when rename unsaved file in **Visual Studio Code 1.5.3**

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/344784/19231536/b60b667a-8f04-11e6-94c7-ee1d2b3c5042.png)
Dialog box when rename (saved) file in **Visual Studio 2015**

Note that rename saved file in **Visual Studio Code** does not ask for anything.

data.title: Shortcut to recently opened projects / folders to open VS Code with
data.body: I always open VS 2015 projects by right clicking on the taskbar icon, and choosing the project I want from the "Recent" list. In VS Code this option is not available, and I have to open VS Code first, and then open the recent project I want.

data.title: Info/Error Bar messages should specify their source

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
As a user, it can be difficult to diagnose issues when there are multiple extensions installed because it's not always clear whether it's an extension, or vscode, and if it's an extension, which one is it? This causes confusion like https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/13356. 

What if infobars also specified the original source, rather than putting the onus on extension authors to be sufficiently descriptive with every single message string they write? Or maybe we could provide a standard way of jumping to further documentation about the message? (Right now, you can sort of do that by specifying a custom button, but it may be worth providing a little more consistency here)
